Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Characterizing floodplain deposition from Hurricane Irene along the Lower Connecticut River
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will document sedimentation from Hurricane Irene in floodplain environments along the Lower Connecticut River to gain insight into the significance of these rare events in building the landscape of a low-gradient river system. The work will be done by collecting transects of cores at six previously sampled sites. Beryllium-7 will be used to identify recent sedimentation in these cores. In addition, the project will evaluate the composition and contaminant levels in the Irene deposits relative to deeper sediments already obtained at each of the six locations.

An accurate understanding of the evolution of fluvial landscapes involves knowing the role of extreme flooding in the distribution and/or remobilization of sediment along a river's floodplain. Such information is often challenging to acquire due to the rarity of such events. The high precipitation associated with Hurricane Irene offers one such rare example for eastern US coastal rivers (indeed, extreme flooding by Irene presents an opportunity to revisit unanswered questions on the contribution of 1955 hurricane-related sedimentation to floodplain evolution along the Lower Connecticut River). From a land use perspective, most east coast rivers have a legacy of contaminants now stored in floodplain sediments. Sampling sediment deposited after Irene?s flooding will provide an opportunity to assess the role extreme events play in the storage and/or remobilization of this material.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tropical cyclones provide the dominant mechanism for extreme precipitation for most major North American rivers draining into the western North Atlantic, yet observations have been lacking on the magnitude and type of material transported by these events. This small RAPID grant provided support to study effects of Hurricane Irene in 2011 on the Connecticut River and in doing so provided rare insight into the behavior of an east coast river to one such extreme precipitation event.  The study is significant in that it provides: i)  new empirical observations on the role of high-magnitude, low frequency flood events relative to more routine seasonal discharge events in removing sediments from this landscape, ii) a rare modern assessment of the characteristics of resultant sedimentation from extreme precipitation relative to sediments deposited by more routine seasonal flooding, and iii) extends these two evaluations to a new environment (i.e. glacially conditioned watersheds of the Atlantic Slope). 

Rivers of note that drain glacially conditioned landscapes of the western Atlantic Slope include the Susquehanna, Delaware, Hudson and Connecticut Rivers. This study advances our understanding for the role of extreme precipitation events in contribute sediment, organics, and contaminants by these major river systems to some of the most productive estuaries and active ports and harbors in North America, including Chesapeake Bay, Delaware Bay, New York Harbor, and Long Island Sound. This knowledge is critical for developing effective river/estuarine management strategies.

The effects of Hurricane Irene on the Connecticut River provide rare insight into the behavior of an east coast river to extreme precipitation. First hand reconnaissance shortly after the event document newly formed gullies and channel incision proving rare and widespread access to legacy fines within glacial drift still common to the uplands of the river system. Once mobilized, these fine grained sediments were rapidly transported to the river mouth, diluting particulate organics, and capping contaminated industrial depocenters with a relatively clean and impermeable layer of inorganic clays and silts. When compared to sedimentation from the preceding spring flood Irene sediments exhibited a unique depositional imprint consistent with the enhanced fluvial supply of chemically immature fines from rejuvenated glacial drift deposits that have remained untouched within much of the northeast since the last major glaciation. Our results highlight extreme precipitation as a primary mechanism for removing this material from upland catchments.  We calculate that sediment yield during the event from just one upland tributary comprising 5% of the entire Connecticut River watershed accounted for approximately 40% of the total sediment load exiting the Connecticut River. Calculated sediment yields for this single upland catchment is estimated to be at least 350 tonnes/km^2. This upland sediment yield exceeds the cumulative sediment contributions by the watershed over the last 40 yrs, thus highlighting the importance of events like Irene in removing material from these upland catchments. On average we show that sediment discharge has been between 50-100% higher in the two years following Irene when compared to sediment discharge prior to the event.
